intro: Ipomoea barteri var. longisepala, commonly known as the long-sepaled morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its large, showy flowers that typically bloom in the morning and close in the afternoon. The plant has heart-shaped leaves and produces tendrils that help it climb and support its growth. Its flowers come in shades of purple, pink, and white, and they are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects. The species is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is part of the Convolvulaceae family.
